bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to M.J. Rosenau, November 2, 1924

div1.p: [Carter] writes that he believes there was no yellow fever in Mexico at the time of the Spanish conquest.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to M.J. Rosenau, November 2, 1924
div1.opener:
/LC
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
November 2, 1924.
Dr. M. J. Rosenau,
Department of Preventive Medicine and Hygiene,
Medical School, Harvard University, Boston, Mass.
Dear Doctor Rosenau:
div1.p:
Your letter came Friday and the MS Saturday, with the notes
interleaved in it. Thank you very much for your good opinion of it.
I too think it convincing as far as I have gone.

About the Maya country: It might have been better to have given
only the translations of such parts of their MSS as I used (all avail-
able which bear on the subject, I think). The insertion of the origi-
nal may have broken the thread of the narrative. On the other hand, I
did not want Maya scholars--like Mr. Spinden--to say that I had mis-
quoted, or mistranslated these records: especially as I had to take
issue with old Bishop Carillo in a translation, the very text of which
was in question.

I did do a good deal of study on this matter: Beltran's and
Padre Buenaventura's grammars and two or three imperfect dictionaries.
I think I put all of six weeks--maybe eight--on the photostat of the
Chumayel books and have quite a lot of it translated--after a fashion.
There was nothing else to do. I doubt if further archaelogical re-
-2-
re-
search in that country will give any data on this subject not already
available. I would like, however, to have a full translation (or a
photostat) of the Tizimen MS. That of Mani--in Brinton's opinion the
most reliable of all--has disappeared.

Guiteras accepts my finding that there was no yellow fever in
the tierra caliente or elsewhere in Mexico at the time of the Conquest,
but is not equally convinced about its absence in Yucatan. In my judge-
ment the argument is more convincing for the latter than for Mexico, be-
cause (1) we have a better native history in Yucatan than we have for
Mexico: (2) During the Conquest of Yucatan (from 1528 to 1541 inclusive)
all of the action took place on the low-lands (there are no high lands)
now infectable territory where Stegomyia abound; while most of the ac-
tion of the Mexican Conquest (1519-21 only) was on the plateau and the
absence of any note of yellow fever in either country means more for
itsthe absence of the disease from Yucatan than it does for Mexico (a) on account of the
nature of the terrain and (b) the greater time spent there.

(3) There is a fairly complete sanitary history, direct or im-
plied, of Yucatan for 107 years after its conquest, during which time
it was quite thoroughly settled, and not thinly settled, by Spaniards
with no evidence of yellow fever; and (4) an epidemic of yellow Fever in 1648 evidently
among a people, Spaniards and Indians, virgin to this infection and
clearly unknown to the former. This latter is the same evidence that
Finlay relies on when he counts the epidemic of 1649 the first that
ever visited Cuba.

I think the absence of yellow fever from Yucatan about the time
of the Conquest--say from 85 years before to 107 after it--is as nigh
proven as one can well prove a negative propostion.

I am going to write you a Memorandum about your suggestions
seriatum--and some of them are going to be quite long. You have made
me think.

With very best remembrances to yourself and Mrs. Rosenau, in
which Laura, who is writing this, joins,
